Award.AwardTitle: Core Support for the NRC Geographical Sciences Committee

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Research Council (NRC) established a Geographical Sciences Committee (GSC) in 1997 because spatial and place-based approaches to human-environment science had demonstrated themselves to be of increasing importance in addressing major societal and environmental topics. This award renews core support for the GSC, which has as its mission: (1) to bring the theories and perspectives of the geographical sciences to bear on society's problems; (2) to foster international cooperation by serving as a liaison to other national geographical organizations and initiating collaborative research programs among those organizations; (3) to provide advice to the National Academy of Sciences (NAS) on all matters pertaining to geography, especially to the NAS Foreign Secretary on matters concerning international organizations, programs, and research; and (4) to serve as the official U.S. liaison to the International Geographical Union (IGU) and promote and facilitate participation of U.S. geographers in the IGU. The GSC undertakes its work through the conduct of special studies and through meetings. The GSC will identify study topics that will meet the needs of the geographical sciences community and incorporate the recommendations of the 2010 NRC report titled "Strategic Directions for the Geographical Sciences in the Next Decade" into the GSC agenda. The GSC will address both these items through the identification of study tracks related to health; human dimensions of global climate change; and the global recession's role in the restructuring of American society.

Continued support for the GSC will enable this group to bring academics, private sector and government researchers, and policy makers together through roundtables and studies to reach consensus on the most challenging and significant issues in the geographical sciences. The GSC provides a forum to enable geographers to make assessments on the current state of the science and develop a vision for future research directions. GSC activities will enable the geographic sciences in directly inform public policy at the national level. The committee also will advance the role that geographers and related scientists play in a range of contexts in the U.S. and internationally through the International Geographical Union.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The geographical sciences help us understand important relationships between humans and the physical world, and particularly, how the land surface, its natural and constructed features, and humans interact and change. "Place and space" are central to the geographical sciences because they indicate where and under what conditions people, the environment, and the land surface influence one another through time. A large range of important societal issues including human health; land-use and land-use changes; energy, food, and water security; infrastructure development; and human resilience to natural disasters require contributions from the geographical sciences and from policies informed by geographical science information.

   As the focal point for geographical sciences at the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, the Geographical Sciences Committee (GSC) provides independent, unbiased, scientific advice on geographical science issues in response to requests from Congress, federal and state agencies, the geographical science community, and others. The committee also oversees various consensus studies, public meetings, and workshops designed to foster dialogue and constructive action among these stakeholders. During the award period, the GSC oversaw the completion of two consensus reports of the National Academies, hosted two meetings, and served as the U.S. Liaison to the International Geographical Union (IGU) at three IGU meetings.

   The two consensus reports overseen by the GSC and published by the National Academies Press were Advancing Land Change Modeling: Opportunities and Research Requirements (NRC, 2014) and Fostering Tranformative Research in the Geographical Sciences (NASEM, 2015). Both are publicly available for free download. The report on land-change modeling examined how land is used by people (land use) and how changes in the vegetation, rock, and materials that cover the Earth's surface (land cover) can be described and projected using land-change models (LCMs). LCMs are a key way to forecast future landscape conditions and to develop policies to manage resources and the environment. The transformative research report explored the concept and history of transformative research and the way in which transformative research might be fostered by the National Science Foundation, particularly with respect to the geographical sciences. The land change report PDF was downloaded more than 6,000 times by people from 148 countries for purposes as diverse as landscape spatial planning, studying land change, developing land-change models, modeling agricultural crops, and ecosystem accounting. The transformative research report was downladed more than 1,300 times in 92 countries for purposes including surveying research trends and needs, understanding technology trends and gaps, creating regional and national development initatives, and teaching geography at the secondary level. Measurable outcomes of the committee's two reports in future may include incorporation of explicit language in research funding calls for land-change modeling or potentially transformative research; direct recognition and continued support of diversity in the research environment; creation of mechanisms that involve students early in research processes that promote transformative research and thinking; incorporation of LCMs more broadly into land-use planning and decision-making at national, state, and regional levels.

   The committee's two meetings during the award period fostered dialogue among geographers in the federal government, academia, and industry; generated several new ideas for areas in which the GSC could provide assistance to the geographical sciences community; and helped finalize the work plan for a workshop on wildland fire that the committee will oversee in 2017. Participation at the IGU meetings ensured a U.S. perspective was present in discussions and voting on geographical science issue that extend beyond U.S. borders.
